content.description: Scramble up shelf and climb face to shallow corner.
content.location: Route is located to the right of of third dihedral on the wall, route starts on top of shelf.

content.description:
Not the prettiest crack in the Jungle, but one of the best protected and plenty fun. Primarily hands, this crack wavers in size and offers many different options. Follow the crack up and right using a large selection of holds, feet, and jams. Finish at a two-bolt, chain anchor.

While cleaning this line, a few very old, unrecognizable bones were found buried in the crack....ancestors?
content.protection: A single set of cams up to five inches, and a few quick draws.
content.location:
On a small face between

Dr. Livingstone, I Presume?

and

A Fez for Your Monkey

. This is about five feet left of the bolted route

Monkey Business

.

content.description: Five bolts straight up a mini dihedral then right onto the face (while using the chimney when needed), then clip 7 more bolts (12 total) to chains.
content.location: This is the fifth climb on the wall in the Lower Jungle, to the left of "Jungle Boogie."

content.description: The opening move requires a "dyno" if you are less than 6'1" but all moves are well protected with the four bolts all in the right places. You then move right to a sloping ledge where the crack begins; up and left to chains.  This anchor is above the anchor for "Rudyard Kipling," you pass this anchor on your left after clipping the fourth bolt.  Way too bad the rock quality deteriorates so as to prevent topping out on the tower!
content.protection: Four quick draws, three runners, medium to small cams with a few small wires.
content.location: Just around the corner from Rudyard Kipling on what we will be calling "Author's Tower."  This area is known as the "Tower Section" of the Lower Jungle."  That would be the southeast corner of the tower.

content.description: Start in the corner, then move left to the second bolt. Carry on up the wall and finish left to the Allelopathy Arete anchor.
content.location: The wall just right of Allelopathy Arete.

content.description: Shares start and belay with next climb.  Climb face using big hueco  to arete out left.  Use either belay of previous climb or next climb.
content.location: Hike to far end of lower  jungle,  through arch formed by leaning tower and wall with several  climbs on left 30 feet away.  Climb starts in second dihedral and moves left to arete.

content.description: This is the direct start to "Rudyard Kipling."  Very thin moves gets you clipping the second bolt with no room for error on making this clip!  Then moving left to set your first piece is even more important.
content.protection: Two quick draws and a #1 alien, small tri-cams, .4, .5, .75, and a #1 gets you to the top.
content.location: Directly under "Rudyard Kipling."

content.description:
Pull some hard moves on 10ft of not so great rock past the first 2 bolts (I would stickclip the 2nd bolt). This leads to a discontinuous crack system which is followed to a small roof. Pull the roof right passing 2 more bolts. Then up a left leaning flake and horizontal to 2 more bolts.

Finish left to same anchor as Shere Khan. Well worth a top rope after you do Shere Khan.

Sustained with miles of good climbing.
content.protection:
Bolts.

Lots of small/med wires, cams up to a green metolius. Save a blue Metolius and some small wires for the horizontal near top.
content.location: Starts 10ft right of Shere Khan.

content.description:
Start up a small left facing corner, then face climb up and then left onto the arete. Some tricky moves back right leads you to a flake and then to the base of nice fingercrack.

Up this to the anchor.

Great climb on perfect rock.
content.protection:
Bolts.

Blue and small nut between bolts 2 and 3.

Red, black, yellow and double orange's for the upper crack.

All cams Metolius.
content.location: Starts 20ft right of Monkey Fist on the front of the obvious orange buttress.

content.description: Climb face and seam
content.location: Route is 25 ft to the right of rikki tikki tavi.

content.description: A thin traverse leads to an excellent thin hands crack to the top.
content.protection: One bolt for the traverse, gear to 1" (though mostly .75" and smaller), bolted anchor with rap chains. Have the belayer sit on the ledge to the left of the bolt in order to protect the leader's potential swing during the traverse.
content.location: Out the Lower Jungle trail past King Kong. You will pass through a large split boulder, at which point the tower with Rudyard Kipling comes into view. Rudyard Kipling is the obvious crack on the face that you'll see from the trail.

content.description: Superb and sustained climbing up the blunt arete leads you to a good rest where you were hoping the anchor was going to be. Look up at the overhanging crack, take a deep breath and off you go. Wild finish, brilliant route.
content.protection:
Bolts.

Yellow, black metolius, 2 hand size pieces and an orange metolius were used for the finish.
content.location: Starts 30ft right of Concrete Jungle and about 50ft before (left of) Gooseberry Corner.

content.description:
Move left to the arete then crank a few moves to below a roof. Pull the roof to a rest, finish up with some tricky moves to the anchor.

Nice climb on good rock.
content.location: 20ft right of Congo Crack.

content.description: A short, two bolt face to chains.  Good warm up or beginner climb. The face moves are much harder and you clip with a right hand.  The crack is somewhat interesting and you clip with the left.
content.location: In the Lower Jungle to the right of "Homo cragus" and about mid way through the Lower Jungle. This is the last route on the short cliff, a.k.a. "The Pygmy Wall." Easy to find because it is so short...set up to teach kids how to lead.

content.description:
Start will small edges and good sidepulls to reach a high first bolt, stemming as needed against a low angle slab covered in gooseberry (or wild rose, one of those thorny fuckers which grow all over the Jungle).

Balance your way around a micro roof and along the edge of a nearly featureless panel of red stone then pull a thugish (or technical, your call) mantle on a narrow ledge. Pull down (not out) to establish in the corner forming the left edge of another immaculate shield, avoiding the left arete which we

purposely

did not clean (makes for an easy escape on shitty rock that would never clean-up, attempt at your own risks). Exit the corner by latching on to some threatening-looking yet solid blocks and mantle on a ledge to clip the anchors from the left (easier) or swing right for a final face sequence on small holds (harder).

Roy had sniffed out this nice pillar a couple minutes from the car and we decided to close the season with it. Filling in the blanks at the Lower Jungle...
content.location:
PTP is located on the left side of the alcove which is also home to

Mistah Kurtz - he dead.

and

Monkey Fist

(easily seen from the Lower J parking lot). Look for a tapering pillar on the SE face of a detached tower. A very distinctive sheet of blank rock forms the upper third of the route.

content.description: Up the finger crack to a few stout moves left into the wide, then anchor. Good rock yet again.
content.location: The finger crack 5ft left of the obvious Bring the Machete corner.

content.description: Scramble up shelf and lay back flaring shallow bolted crack to right of yours truly and move to crack to the right that requires cams, .75 to 1.75 inch.
content.protection: bolts and cams for .75 to 1.75 inch
content.location: Bolted crack to the right of yours truly and move to crack on right

climbs.name: Oranguterror
climbs.fa: Pitch I    R. Suggett, R. Magner, P. Curry   Pitch II  Marilla Lamb and Mitch Yaggie

content.description:
This sport route is even better as the thin edges have lost the lichen. The second clip is important!  This is the first pitch crux and if you peel after pulling rope prior to the clip...there is a possibility of hitting something hard on the fall.  The stance is what we all thought was the best option, but still...be careful!  As of 6/15/14 there is now a second pitch.  The 11d moves are on this pitch and come at the second to last bolt.  The first pitch is still an 11a.  You can do the entire thing as one pitch if you have forearms like Popeye OR go to the shared anchor with "Coco's Lichen It" as before.  So...

Pitch I  Seven bolts to a two bolt anchor with rings.  This anchor is shared with the crack just to the left.  Climb up the arete then left on to the face.  The line is mostly straight up until the last bolt when it turns left.

Pitch II  Traverse right from the last bolt of pitch I and head up and toward the wall (which looks doable...check it out on the top rope) and then straight up, clipping the last of six bolts before reaching the two bolt anchor.  A 60 meter rope will suffice. This pitch was a collaborative effort!  Early in the 2014 season R. Magner and I bolted and cleaned it a bit. The lateness of the day and the rocks wizzing by our heads sent us home with the job unfinished.  Later, Alexie and Drew finished cleaning it.  Then in late Aug. the FFA (see coments below).
content.protection: Quick draws to shuts (Pitch 1) and M.Rap hangers on the second pitch.
content.location: This face is just right of a right facing dihedral with the crack called "Coco's Lichen It."  This is the second to last of the routes in the "Congo Corner."

content.description: The route starts on a stellar lie-back, 10c then into a gnarley offwidth which leads to a ledge where a short but sweet hands/fingers crack (the crux) that leads to the upper face moves of "The Missing Link." You can place pro or use the last two bolts of "The Missing Link."
content.protection: A wide assortment of cams with at least three #3s and three #4s gets you to the chain anchor. As you exit the lie-back and head around to the west side, DO NOT STEP INTO THE TALUS CHUTE!  Stay on the wall or risk sending tons of washing-machine-sized boulders down on your belayer!
content.location: The route is just right of the "Direct Start of The Missing Link"(a.k.a. Java Man) on the North and West side of this tower as it leans against the main  "Welcome Wall."

content.description: This route is on a triangular-shaped pillar mid-way in the Lower Jungle.  The bolts are right of the arete though the climb may dictate switching from right to left and back across the arete OR hang on (left hand & "thumb") for a wild and slightly more demanding ride completely on the right.
content.location: To the left and around the corner of "Knuckle Draggers Needed."  A new climb on a second arete "Allelopathy Arete" is just left of this climb.  A pillar very close to these climbs has yet another arete to be put up!  Three aretes in a row would be cool! This corner forms the end of the "Wailing Wall."

content.description:
The FA started up the crack/face then moved on to the face proper by the second bolt. We later did it direct and up's the ante to 11a.

Great Rock.
content.location: On the face left of Opposable Thumbs.

content.description: This is an excellent sport crack in a paper thin line that opens to finger locks on a smooth face.
content.location: This thin crack starts just left of "A Fez for Your Monkey," and is just right and around from a prominent point on the cliff where a large Sub Alpine Fir grows. The trail squeezes between these two features and thus begins the "Wombat Wall."

content.description: Off-width taking at least four #4s and one #5 along with some other miscellaneous cams leading straight up to a ledge where face moves take you right and up past three bolts to chains. The crux seems to be getting into the main crack.
content.protection: At least four #4s, one #5, an assortment of other cams, 3 quickdraws, runners.
content.location: This new route, put up on 7/4/11 by JoFo, is to the right of "Nit Picking," and is the obvious vetical off-width crack you can see from the parking area. It starts in a broken and tree filled corner that forms the end of the "Welcome Wall."

content.description:
A devious and steep face with technical moves and a powerful crux. Pretty to look at...and smart too!

Monkey Business

takes the direct line up the face and follows a faint, thin crack. Good rock, good moves! Pumpy and sustained. Bring some brain power as well, this routes requires a little

monkey business

!
content.protection: Seven bolts and a chain anchor.
content.location:
On a small face between

Dr. Livingstone, I Presume?

and

A Fez for Your Monkey

. This is the clean face with bolts just above the trail.

content.description:
A nice climb split into 2 sections with a big rest in the middle.

10+ if you step in to the corner then back left.

11a if you go straight.

A decent route to get the fingers going.
content.location: Starts in the alcove a few feet left of Monkey Fist.

content.description: The route starts with consistent 9+ and 10a moves on the east side of the block then traverses around the corner to the north side where the climbing and the rock quality both get harder.  At the sixth bolt, use a long runner and then start following the line that arches right.  The line that goes left is another route (Jungle Boogie).  You must traverse a thin section to a large ledge which is around the corner and not obvious.  The traverse is the first crux but really fun. Clip the high bolt on the ledge with a runner.  The lower grey hanger is part of the direct start(a.k.a. Java Man).  Follow the ramp past two more bolts.  The real crux is now getting past the final and twelth bolt.  While on the north side you will be out of the sight- line of your belayer...comunication is key while making these crutial clips!
content.protection: Twelve bolts takes you up, around the corner, and past the overhanging crack system to chains. Quickdraws and at least four runners.  Note!  The bolt on the corner is good but needs some more work... somehow I screwed that one up a bit.
content.location: This route is just a few climbs right (north) from the first climbs you see in the Lower Jungle on the "Welcome Wall."  That is, same start as Jungle Bogie but cuts right around the arete.

climbs.name: The Man Who Would Be King

content.description: Great climbing up a perfect corner.
content.location: The tight corner, which is the fourth climb right of the obvious DS corner. Right of Every Body Drops.

content.description: Tricky moves to a bouldery crux, then nice wall climbing to finish. Great rock
content.location: 30ft right of DR. Livingstone I Presume

content.description: This route is on a north, right-facing dihedral.  Using the first move of "Diverging Evolution" crack, reach over left and clip the first bolt before stepping out on the face.  Three bolts later you reach a ledge and are able to clip the fourth bolt for the crux move.  The crux can be height-dependent and shorter climbers may need to make the clip and climb down working left onto the arete.  In any event, the arete leads to chains.  Really fun route!
content.protection: 8 quick draws and a few runners.
content.location: Lower Jungle in the "Congo Corner" left of "Diverging Evolution."

content.description: Clipping and moving past the second bolt is the crux.  Fun moves on too short of a route!
content.location: First route on Author's Tower and shares an anchor with "Rudyard Kipling."

content.description:
10 bolts + chains

the start still needs some cleaning but the upper section is pretty solid
content.location: far right of lower jungle

content.description: This is a climb where every move seems to be either a 9+ or a 10a.  The more unusual moves, thus the crux, are between the 7th and the 8th bolts.  As you start, try to stay right of the less than solid rock.  Rock quality improves as you go higher. As you climb follow the line that arches left.  At the sixth bolt another route (The Missing Link) takes off right and around the corner.  This is much harder climbing!  The two routes share the same start but have separate anchors.
content.protection: Eight quickdraws and a couple of runners gets you to chains.
content.location: Just right of "Welcome To The Jungle" on the "Welcome Wall."

content.description: Some tricky back and forth up the arete until you can move right on to the green face. Up this to a ledge, then finish up the last few bolts of Missing Link to the anchor.
content.location: Starts up the arete a few feet right of Missing Link.

content.description: Climb shallow open book to upper face  on tentative jams and edges to occasional jugs. Constantly ever changing climbing.  Crux near the top.
content.location: This route is located about 15 ft. right of Ape shit.

content.description: This is an excellent face climb between "Pygmy" and "Blue Collar Ape."  Start using the arete and crack passing first bolt to a large ramp.  Being careful, clip the second bolt around the corner where the face climbing begins.  Five bolts total to shunts shared by Blue Collar Ape.
content.location: Lower Jungle between "Blue Collar Ape" & "Hey, Hey, We're the Monkeys

content.description: This is a really nice dihedral leading to a roof and finishes at the same anchor as Homo Cragus.  The crux is in the first 8 feet where the face is smooth at your feet.  Fun stemming thereafter. Have fun searching for the hidden bomber hold on the ceiling.
content.protection: 6 bolts to 2 strut anchor.  Last bolt shared with Homo Cragus.  Anchor shared with Homo Cragus and Blue Collar Ape.
content.location: The route starts in the obvious dihedral just right of Homo Cragus.

content.description: Typical Jungle, the crux is at the end.  Clip the last bolt, turn the arete, and traverse left on overhanging rock before moving up and right to the chains.  Fun moves throughout!
content.protection: Nine QDs and three shoulder length runners gets you to chains.
content.location: This line shares the start to the famous "Welcome To The Jungle" line but does not traverse right on to the northwest face but rather continues straight up on ever steeping rock.

content.description: An off-width crack inside a chimney.  Not as bad as it looks, though.  Chains at the top.
content.location: In the Lower Jungle on the "Pygmy Wall" right of "Funky Monkey."  This is in a north facing, right-sided dihedral that shares an anchor with the bolted sport route, "Funky Monkey," to the left. (see beta/topo photo)

content.description: Climb up a short chossy section (with a mantle over the thorny goosberry) to a ledge.  From there, a nice dihedral with a good crack and plenty of edges on the sidewalls offer varied climbing through a few exciting bulges.  The route ends on a small stance at a two bolt/chain anchor.
content.protection: 1-2 sets of cams from finger size to approx. #4 camalot sized... medium and large stoppers are handy.
content.location: This is the somewhat acute dihedral system about 40 feet left of "Opposable Thumbs Required".

content.description: Crack to belay
content.location: Crack 6-7 ft. to the right of ""the overdoit," currently furthest right route and about 150 ft. from leaning tower. Shares ending with previous route.

climbs.name: George
climbs.fa: Trevor Bowman, R. Suggett and Gene Vallee

content.description: Unlike many Jungle lines the crux is not at the start or the end but right in the middle. Though the rest of the moves are all hard there is a height dependent left hand at the crux that may be frustrating for those under 5' 10".
content.protection: Six bolts to chains.  QDs all the way
content.location: Just left of "Knuckle Draggers Needed" and shares the last two bolts and anchor. On a narrow west face where both aretes can and will be used.

climbs.name: Furious George
climbs.fa: Brent Barghahn, Ally Lamb, Dan Noll

content.description:
Pitch 1: Climb up the sustained thin crack 10ft right of Rikki Tikki Tavi. Good gear with face climbing movement. Gently pull over or skirt around the upper blocks (too solid to trundle) and walk the ramp right to a bolted anchor. A throw away approach pitch, climb P2 before rating the line 5.10

Pitch 2: Where else to go but up the tips layback! Float your way up the splitter and mantle up under the roof. Look upward and ponder reaching the overhead bolt while as pumped as you are. Once past the bolt, trend left to a hidden crack, then up through a short flare chimney. Clip one last bolt to keep your follower safe, then step left to an anchor and scenic stance. 5.11+

Single rap from the top anchor gets you down with a 60m
content.protection: Single rack with extra 0.2-0.3 X4/1-2 C3 pieces.
content.location: Start 10ft right of Rikki Tikki Tavi for the first pitch. The second pitch continue rightward above the ledge and can be seen from the path

content.description: Climb the arete while using the shaded north face past five bolts of fun moves.
content.protection: Five quick draws gets you to chains at the top.
content.location: In the Lower Jungle, right of "Bungle in the Jungle" on a north facing short wall which forms a distinct corner and the start of the cliff section known as the "Pygmy Wall."

climbs.name: Flaky Chimp
climbs.fa: Roy Suggett R. Magner and Jim Mathews

content.description: Five bolts through some iffy holds leads to chains.
content.protection: Quick draws and a helmet for the belayer.
content.location: Lower Jungle on the "Pygmy Wall" just right of "The Great Rift Valley."

content.description: Pull through the crumbly first 10 feet up into the double cracks, featuring a lovely splitter on the left! Stem, jam, and continue up the fluctuating crack through a wide pod and a pinched off section. Once the crack seams out, a creative transfer left gets you to the final 20ft splitter finger crack. Crank through this to the bolted anchor.
content.protection: Single rack. Save finger pieces for the splitter up top. 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: The corner system just left of Concrete jungle.

content.description: Climb 2nd dihedral to the right using large heuco and following corner seam. Traverse right at second to last bolt to corner then up.
Starts a bit flaky but gets better, crux going by second bolt. Pumpy.
content.location: The face/crack left of Axl Rose's Intro

content.description:
A great looking route that is a good route, which will become a great route with a few more sends.(if you get my drift)

Tricky stems at the start to nice mellow climbing the rest of the way.
content.location: Obvious corner 30ft right of Daniel Quinn/Arch

content.description: Hard bouldery moves up the thin seam lead to a easier finish. Perfect rock.
content.location: About 50ft right of Monkey Trick/Fez for your Monkey.

content.description: This route shares the same start as "Coco's Lichen It" then diverges up and left to chains.
content.location: Lower Jungle between "Coco's Lichen It" and "Knuckle Draggers Needed." This route is the vertex of the "Congo Corner."

content.description: This route starts hard and gradually gets easier.  As more climbing goes on here the lichen will disapear and the holds will become more positive.
content.protection: Seven quick draws and three runners.  Seven bolts lead to shuts.
content.location: This route is on the north side of Author's Tower and is the last route in the Lower Jungle. Step out of the tunnel formed by the tower leaning against the cliff and turn right. An unusual move gets you clipping the first bolt and HOPING to clip the second!

content.description: Sweet little route on bomber rock. Bouldery over the roof to anchor.
content.location: Bolted arete/face left of Peachy Carnehan crack.

content.description: Nice climbing that builds the higher you go.
content.location: Starts on the wall just left of Monkey Trick

content.description: The crack has some good climbing though its a bit flakey in the middle section.
content.protection:
Cams from 1/2" to 4", med/lg stoppers.

Bolt anchor.
content.location: Next crack right of A Fez for your Monkey.

content.description: Climb the face past a blank looking corner to the anchor, just left of a bush.
content.location: 20ft right of Star of Astoroth.

climbs.name: Coco's Lichen It
climbs.fa: R. Magner, R. Suggett, and P. Curry

content.description: This crack is in an orange lichened, right facing dihedral with the exit as the crux.
content.protection: A varied assortment of cams is needed to reach the same shuts that "Oranguterror" uses.
content.location: This crack is just left of "Orranguterror" for which it shares the anchor and just right of "Divergent Evolution" and is in the area known as the "Congo Corner."

content.description: Hands to fist and wider
content.location: 10 feet left of "Easy Like Sunday Morning"

content.description: Nice crimping to mellow finish.
content.location: Face 20ft right of Java Man/Nit Picking

content.description: Four bolts to chains on a face/arete climb.  This route can be done without the arete but this increases the difficulty.
content.location: This climb is between "Dr. Livingstone, I Presume," and "Funky Monkey."  This route is at the end of a long section the cliff which is known as the "Wombat Wall."

climbs.name: Bring the Machete
climbs.fa: Sean McLane and Levi Call, July 2019

content.description: Start in a wide, left-facing corner crack, then take a series of three "staircase" edges left past two bolts into a tips crack. Above the tips, juggy, somewhat runout (look closely for good gear, it's there) 5.9 climbing puts you under an overhanging block protected by a bolt. A final splitter crack leads through the roof to the anchors.
content.location: Hike 5-10 minutes to the right side of the Lower Jungle. This is the second route on Kong Tower, to the right of King Kong. It starts across from the Author's Tower routes in a short, left-facing dihedral.

content.description: This is a very fun zigzagging route with a scary reach problem at the third bolt.  Otherwise, the climb is made up of mostly 5.7 and 5.8 moves.  Five bolts to shuts.
content.location: In the Lower Jungle on the "Pygmy Wall" right of "Flaky Chimp" and just left of "Homo cragus" of which it shares the anchor.

content.description: This crack starts as an off-width and is a bit awkward but soon turns to hands and the face edges also help.  The upper section of the crack merges with "Upton Sinclair" and they share the same chains.
content.protection: LARGE cams to small wires.  A #5 and a #6 cam. would be nice.
content.location: This crack is on the north east corner of Author's Tower.  Author's Tower is easy to find in that it forms a tunnel over the trail.  Go through the tunnel and then down and right.

content.description: This off-width soon becomes a chimney and is difficult to protect.  The moves, however, are fairly secure and fun if you like this sort of old school climbing.
content.location: This route lies just right of "Bad Banana Dreams" on the Wombat Wall and they share the same anchor.

content.description: Starts on great rock then takes you to the interface  between poor quality and good rock.  At this point, two bolts lead you right with your feet on the good rock to chains.
content.location: Just to the right of "Concrete Jungle" on the Wombat Wall.

content.description: The first moves are the crux.  After this the crack takes small cams well and the face is fun to climb.  The upper bolted section looks hideous, but nonetheless has solid edges to move into the chimney.  Stay off the floor (loose rock) and move up the chimney clipping bolts.
content.location: One of the first lines you will see in the LG.

content.description: This exciting Congo Corner edition is a stiff lead!  Do not be sucked in unknowingly to its initial 9+ moves.  Climb through those edgy face moves to the short crack.  Jam up this to the second bolt.   Delicately work through some small under clings and traverse left. Be rewarded by a "thank God hold to clip the next bolt.  Move up and right to clip the fifth and take a big breath. The BIG crux move is followed by small edges  on good face, thus avoiding the corner on the right.  This is a VERY technical line throughout!
content.protection: Twelve QDs and runners for the two bolt anchor.
content.location: Just right of Oranguterror and shares the last three bolts and anchor.

content.description: Climb the arete (mostly on the left side, or directly on it, using both sides) passing 9 bolts on the way to a two bolt/chain anchor.  Good rock, with very technical climbing at the crux and sustained climbing throughout.
content.location:
This is the nice, square arete, located in between "Gooseberry Corner" and "Opposable Thumbs Required".

Approximately 10 feet right of Gooseberry.

content.description: A bit of a chausey crack with a bolt mid way up.  This route most likely was designed to set up an anchor for the route just left which is hard and very good.
content.protection: Small cams and wires past one bolt to anchor.
content.location: Just around the corner from a large, sub-Alpine fir in the middle of the primitive trail.  This route is just right of "Monkey Trick" for which it shares an anchor and in the area known as the "Wombat Wall." (see beta/topo photo on front page)
